nodes.name: Framing
nodes.description: Presenting information in a way that influences perception
nodes.longDescription: Framing refers to how information is presented to influence interpretation. The same facts can be framed differently to produce different reactions. For example, '90% survival rate' sounds more positive than '10% mortality rate', though they mean the same thing.
nodes.example: Calling tax cuts 'relief' vs. 'giveaways to the rich'
nodes.extendedExample: Political framing: 'death tax' vs. 'estate tax', 'climate change' vs. 'global warming'. Media framing: focusing on individual crime stories creates fear, while statistical context shows declining crime rates.
empiricalEvidence: News framing effects on public opinion (Iyengar, 1991)
counterStrategies: Reframe the issue from multiple perspectives
Look for absolute numbers behind percentages
Ask 'How else could this be described?'

nodes.name: Emotional Appeal
nodes.description: Triggering emotions to bypass rational analysis
nodes.longDescription: Emotional appeals exploit our tendency to make decisions based on feelings rather than facts. Fear, anger, hope, and disgust can overwhelm logical thinking and critical evaluation.
nodes.example: Using fear of terrorism to justify surveillance
nodes.extendedExample: Political ads showing suffering children, disaster footage, or patriotic imagery. Marketing using happiness, sex appeal, or FOMO (fear of missing out). Propaganda using outrage and moral disgust.
counterStrategies: Notice when you feel strong emotions
Pause and ask 'What facts support this claim?'
Separate the emotional content from the argument

nodes.name: Appeal to Authority
nodes.description: Using perceived expertise or status to make claims credible
nodes.longDescription: We tend to trust experts and authorities, which can be exploited. Fake experts, credentials, or simply authoritative presentation can lend undeserved credibility to claims.
nodes.extendedExample: Celebrity endorsements, white lab coats in ads, made-up credentials, selective expert quotation, citing authorities outside their field of expertise.

uncertainty.basis: Milgram's obedience studies and related research

empiricalEvidence: Expert influence on jury decisions (Cooper et al., 1996)
counterStrategies: Check credentials and expertise area
Look for consensus among experts
Evaluate arguments independent of who makes them

nodes.name: Ad Hominem
nodes.description: Attacking the person instead of their argument
nodes.longDescription: Rather than addressing an argument's merits, ad hominem attacks focus on the character, motives, or circumstances of the person making it. This deflects from substantive discussion.
nodes.example: You're just saying that because you're paid by them
nodes.extendedExample: Dismissing climate science because scientists receive funding, attacking political opponents' personal lives, questioning someone's patriotism instead of their policy proposal.
empiricalEvidence: Political attack ad effectiveness (Lau et al., 1999)
counterStrategies: Separate the argument from the arguer
Ask 'Does this address the actual claim?'
Steel-man the argument: present it in its best form

nodes.name: Straw Man
nodes.description: Misrepresenting an opponent's position to make it easier to attack
nodes.longDescription: The straw man fallacy involves distorting or oversimplifying someone's position, then attacking this weaker version instead of their actual argument. This creates the illusion of winning a debate.
nodes.example: They want to defund police means they want total lawlessness
nodes.extendedExample: Reducing nuanced policy proposals to extreme caricatures, taking quotes out of context, conflating different positions, or attributing extreme views to moderate opponents.
counterStrategies: Seek out the original source
Ask 'Is this what they actually said?'
Look for the strongest version of opposing views

nodes.name: False Dichotomy
nodes.description: Presenting only two options when more exist
nodes.longDescription: False dichotomy (or false dilemma) presents a situation as if only two choices exist, when in reality there are multiple options or middle grounds. This simplification can manipulate by excluding reasonable alternatives.
nodes.example: You're either with us or against us
nodes.extendedExample: Framing debates as liberty vs. security, economic growth vs. environment, tradition vs. progress - ignoring nuanced positions that balance multiple values.
counterStrategies: Ask 'What other options exist?'
Look for middle ground and hybrid solutions
Recognize that most issues are multi-dimensional

nodes.name: Social Proof
nodes.description: Using others' behavior to validate actions or beliefs
nodes.longDescription: We tend to do what we see others doing, especially in uncertain situations. This can be manipulated through fake testimonials, manufactured consensus, or highlighting selected examples of behavior.
nodes.extendedExample: Canned laughter in TV shows, manipulated like counts, astroturfing campaigns, selective polling presentation, bandwagon appeals in politics.
counterStrategies: Ask 'Are these people credible sources?'
Consider that popular ≠ correct
Evaluate evidence independently of crowd behavior

nodes.name: Scarcity
nodes.longDescription: We value things more when they're scarce or in limited supply. Artificial scarcity - limited time offers, exclusive access, countdown timers - can pressure decisions without rational evaluation.
nodes.example: Only 3 left in stock! Order now!
nodes.extendedExample: Flash sales, limited editions, exclusive memberships, early bird specials. In politics: framing resources as scarce to justify competition over cooperation.
counterStrategies: Take time before urgent decisions
Ask 'Will this still be worthwhile tomorrow?'
Recognize artificial scarcity tactics

nodes.name: Priming
nodes.description: Exposure to stimuli influencing subsequent responses
nodes.longDescription: Priming occurs when exposure to one stimulus influences response to another. Subtle cues - words, images, music - can unconsciously affect judgments and behavior that follow.
nodes.example: Playing patriotic music before a political message
nodes.extendedExample: Grocery stores playing slow music to increase browsing time, news using dramatic music before stories, websites using specific color schemes to influence mood and decisions.

uncertainty.basis: Mixed replication results in recent years

counterStrategies: Be aware of context and environmental cues
Take breaks to reset mental state
Make important decisions in neutral environments

nodes.name: Equivocation
nodes.longDescription: Equivocation exploits ambiguity by using words with multiple meanings or vague terms that can be interpreted differently. This allows making claims that sound definitive but are actually evasive.
nodes.extendedExample: Political promises using vague terms like 'soon', 'significant', or 'looking into it'. Marketing claims that sound impressive but are technically meaningless.
counterStrategies: Ask for specific definitions
Look for concrete claims vs. vague promises
Request quantifiable metrics

nodes.name: Narrative Persuasion
nodes.description: Using stories to bypass critical evaluation
nodes.longDescription: Narratives are powerful persuasion tools because they engage us emotionally and reduce critical thinking. Well-crafted stories can make us accept premises we might reject in abstract argument form.
nodes.example: Personal anecdotes presented as evidence for general claims
nodes.extendedExample: Political campaigns using individual stories instead of statistics, brands creating brand narratives, conspiracy theories structured as compelling stories with heroes and villains.
counterStrategies: Distinguish anecdotes from data
Ask 'Is this representative or exceptional?'
Look for systematic evidence beyond stories

nodes.name: Reactance
nodes.description: Triggering opposition to perceived freedom restrictions
nodes.longDescription: When people feel their freedom is threatened, they often react by wanting the forbidden thing more and resisting influence attempts. This can be exploited by framing requests as threats to freedom.
nodes.example: They don't want you to know this!
nodes.extendedExample: Conspiracy theories framing mainstream views as censorship, marketing using 'banned' or 'they tried to stop us' messaging, political rhetoric about threats to liberty.
counterStrategies: Notice when freedom rhetoric is being used
Ask 'Who benefits from my reactance?'
Evaluate claims on merits, not forbidden status

nodes.name: Social Hierarchy
nodes.longDescription: Humans are sensitive to social hierarchies and status. This can be exploited by associating products/ideas with high status, or by manipulating perceptions of social standing.
nodes.example: Luxury brands, exclusive memberships, VIP access
nodes.extendedExample: Marketing products as status symbols, political appeals to group identity and hierarchy, social media influencer culture based on follower counts as status metric.
counterStrategies: Question why status matters for this decision
Evaluate intrinsic value separately from status
Recognize status appeals as manipulation

nodes.name: Collective Orientation
nodes.description: Emphasizing group identity over individual judgment
nodes.longDescription: Collective orientation exploits our tendency to identify with groups. By emphasizing in-group/out-group distinctions, manipulators can bypass individual critical thinking and create 'us vs. them' mentalities.
nodes.extendedExample: Political tribalism, brand communities, sports team loyalty transferred to products, nationalism and xenophobia in politics, cancel culture dynamics.
counterStrategies: Notice when group identity is being invoked
Evaluate claims based on evidence, not tribal loyalty
Recognize that disagreement ≠ disloyalty

metaData.description: Scientific taxonomy of persuasion and manipulation techniques
